Hello sorry about the delay in responding.

The NEAT accelerator speeds up =
the most time consuming portions of the
NEAT algorithm only. Unfortunately =
it won't speed up the other
non-NEAT portions of the problem. If it did, it=
 would simply be a
super computer and then I could charge more and have a m=
uch broader
market :) We are developing it in house to use for accelerating=
 our
own R&D. It could be used, for example as a dedicated NEAT appliance
i=
n a cluster of computers to process the NEAT aspects of the problem.
While =
the other computers work on the non-NEAT parts.

We are in the process of d=
eveloping it. However it looks quite
promising and will definitely help our=
 research. So I was interested
in whether there would be enough commercial =
interest to bring it to
market.

Thank you,

Shane 

--- In neat@yahoogroup=
s.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Shane, 
> 
> Naturally I=
'm very interested in what a NEAT accelerator actually 
> does.  My researc=
h group certainly does a lot of work with NEAT so we 
> would actually purc=
hase something like that (assuming funds were 
> available) if the price wa=
s sufficiently competitive to be faster for 
> the dollar compared to somet=
hing more simple like a regular CPU 
> cluster.
> 
> So I think that is the=
 main pricing question:  For $10,000, if you 
> are efficient, you can buy =
maybe a 20-core cluster, which in effect 
> is a 10x speedup from a regular=
 2-core CPU.  So a 20x speedup sounds 
> economical if it is genuine.
> 
> =
Yet I am not clear how such gains would be made specifically with 
> NEAT i=
n mind?  One of the biggest expenses with running experiments 
> with NEAT =
comes during evaluation in the task domain, which includes 
> a lot of code=
 (aside from the ANN activation method) that is not 
> specific to NEAT.  I=
n fact, in many domains, it is task the domain 
> simulation itself that ta=
kes the vast majority of CPU.  For example, 
> a task trained in a robot si=
mulator spends more time simulating the 
> robot than doing anything NEAT-s=
pecific.  Of course, in some 
> supervised applications (e.g. financial dat=
a) it is possible that 
> network activation takes up more CPU than the dom=
ain since the domain 
> is in effect just a bunch of numerical comparisons.=

> 
> So the questions is what exactly is being accelerated and how, so 
> =
that a purchaser can be confident that they are going to get the 
> offered=
 speedup overall, and not just when NEAT-specific code is 
> being called?
=
> 
> Anyway, sounds really interesting and I'd enjoy hearing more about it.=

> 
> ken
> 
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "shanemcdonaldryan" 
> <s=
hanemcdonaldryan@> wrote:
> >
> > My company is in the process of developin=
g a NEAT accelerator. This 
> > would be a combination of hardware and soft=
ware that accelerates 
> the 
> > process of evolving a population of netwo=
rks for a particular NEAT 
> > application.
> > 
> > We anticipate a 20 fol=
d reduction in training time compared to a 
> > system running on a single =
CPU Dual Core Pentium system. But this 
> > would of course depend greatly =
upon the problem at hand.
> > 
> > The product will consist of an API writt=
en in C that will interface 
> > with a hardware system and accelerate the =
core functionality of the 
> > NEAT algorithm.
> > 
> > A feature set and p=
ricing model has not been finalized.  Though to 
> > make the product finan=
cially viable a tentative price of $10K USD 
> has 
> > been estimated.
> >=
 
> > The reason I am posting is to gauge interest. If you or your 
> compa=
ny 
> > would be interested in this product please send me an e-mail to: 
>=
 > ShaneR at RyanCapital dot EU. Additionally if you have any 
> questions =

> > or concerns please e-mail me or post on this forum and will try and 
>=
 > answer them as quickly as possible.
> > 
> > Thank you,
> > 
> > Shane
>=
